title: The Man from Cairo
text:
The Man from Cairo () is a 1953 British/Italian/American <a href="international%20co-production">international coproduction</a> <a href="film-noir">film noir</a> starring <a href="George%20Raft">George Raft</a>, who plays a man who is mistaken for a detective and sent to find lost <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> gold in <a href="Algiers">Algiers</a>, despite the film's title.
The film was Raft's last with top billing and the last of three films that he made for <a href="Lippert%20Pictures">Lippert Pictures</a>. It was also the final feature film of director <a href="Ray%20Enright">Ray Enright</a> and the American film debut of <a href="Irene%20Papas">Irene Papas</a>.
Plot.
The French government investigates the location of some bullion stolen during the war.
Tourist Mike Canelli, an ex-serviceman who served in Algeria during the war, is mistaken for an American agent assisting the French.
Production.
The film was produced by Bernard Luber, who had just made "<a href="Loan%20Shark%20%28film%29">Loan Shark</a>" with Raft. It was shot on location in Algeria and Italy and was made for $155,000, with $80,000 in deferrals.
Reception.
In a contemporary review for "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>", critic <a href="Howard%20Thompson%20%28film%20critic%29">Howard Thompson</a> found the film to be formulaic but with "a sleazy, authentic-looking backdrop." Thompson wrote: "Lethargically directed by Ray H. Enright, the action soon levels off to a dull, unsurprising trot. ... Mr. Raft is Mr. Raft, still the same competent, brisk and unimaginative performer. ... [T]he rest go through their assigned motions. It takes all of them a long time."
